title: Moduli of curves, sheaves, and K3 surfaces
descriptions:
Abstract:

This grant proposal, titled "Moduli of curves, sheaves, and K3 surfaces," aims to advance the field of algebraic geometry by exploring the rich structures and interconnections within moduli spaces, specifically focusing on curves, sheaves, and K3 surfaces. The project seeks to uncover deep relationships between these spaces and their implications in various branches of mathematics and theoretical physics, including number theory, representation theory, topology, and quantum field theory.

The central research goals of this proposal are multifaceted, targeting the algebra of tautological classes on moduli spaces of curves, the intricate structure of Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas invariants of 3-folds, the analysis of Virasoro constraints, the modular properties of invariants of K3 surfaces, and the investigation of Noether-Lefschetz loci in the moduli of K3 surfaces. To achieve these objectives, the project will utilize a range of innovative methodologies such as virtual localization, degeneration, descendent methods, and log geometry, along with the development of new geometries including moduli spaces of stable quotients and stable pairs.

The significance of this research extends beyond the realm of pure mathematics, as it carries implications for string theory and provides a deeper understanding of classical algebraic geometry through the lens of modern techniques. By harnessing new geometries and innovative techniques, this project promises to offer substantial contributions to the study of moduli spaces, enhancing our comprehension of their mathematical properties and fostering further discoveries in related fields.

Abstract:

This grant proposal, titled "Moduli of curves, sheaves, and K3 surfaces," seeks funding for a cutting-edge research project in the field of Algebraic Geometry. The proposed study will investigate the intricate structures of moduli spaces, which are mathematical spaces that parametrize algebraic curves, sheaves, and the complex geometries of K3 surfaces. This exploration will delve into the algebra of tautological classes, the structure of Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas invariants of 3-folds, and the modular properties and Noether-Lefschetz loci of K3 surface invariants.

Leveraging a suite of innovative methodologies, including virtual localization, degeneration techniques, descendent methods, and log geometry, the research aims to develop new geometries such as moduli spaces of stable quotients and stable pairs. These novel approaches promise to shed light on longstanding questions within Algebraic Geometry and forge connections with related fields such as Number Theory, Representation Theory, Topology, and Quantum Field Theory.

The project's significance is manifold, offering potential breakthroughs in our understanding of moduli spaces—a cornerstone concept in mathematics with profound implications for Topology, String Theory, and Classical Algebraic Geometry. As the nexus of these disciplines, the research outcomes are anticipated to have a transformative impact on the theoretical landscape, opening new avenues for mathematical inquiry and interdisciplinary collaboration.

With a robust research framework and an interdisciplinary team poised to tackle the central questions of the study, this proposal represents an ambitious and exciting opportunity to advance the frontiers of Algebraic Geometry and its applications.
